flowRoot.flowPara: Most of the 3-axis CNC can handle lines and circle-arcs. If we want to create a curve, it is much more interessting to approximate the ideal mathematical curve with arcs than with lines. The error with the Maximum norm might not be smaller. But the approximated curve with arcs has at least a continuous tangent without cusp.
Problematic: Given N lines defined by (N+1) points, how to define the N arcs passing-through the (N+1) points? Can this curve have a continuous tangent?
Three equivalent definitions of an arc
Given (N+1) points (P1 .. P[N+1]) and the tangent direction (t1) of the curve at P1, let's construct the curve (C) made by the following series of N arcs (Arc1 .. ArcN):
- Arc1 is defined with P1, P2 and the tangent direction T1
- Compute the tangente direction T[i+1] of Arc[i] in P[i+1]
- Arc[i+1] is defined with P[i+1], P[i+2] and T[i+1]

The curve (C) is passing through the (N+1) points and its tangent is countinous all over its path. BUT, THIS SOLUTION IS UNSTABLE: the initial tangent gets a huge impact on the overall curve. The oscillation keep increasing !!!
If you can measure the error between (C) and the ideal curve, then you can modify slightly the initial tangent (t1) to minimize the error.
Given a curve, knowning some points with their tangents and their radius of curvature,
how to approxiamte it with arcs?
idea 1: arc defined by start and end points with tangent continuity constraints (ignoring given tangent and radius of curvature) -> bad because local tangent influences the global shape : instable!
idea 2: arc defined by start and end points with average of given tangent (ignoring given radius of curvature) -> bad because no tangent continuity
idea 3: arc defined by 3 points (ignoring given tangent and radius of curvature) -> bad because only every other point is smoothed
idea 4 : arc defined by 3 points (ignoring given tangent and radius of curvature) and computing the intersection with previous and following arc -> bad. it just does not work

idea 5: for each segment, defined two arcs with one point and its tangent (ignoring the radius or curvature) and a constraint of junction between the two arcs with a tangent parallel to the segment. That's the double-arc solution.
(Q) is the line passing through A and an angle with AE equal to u/2
C is the intersection of (R) and (Q)
(S) is the perpendicular to the tangent (At) and passing through A
O is the intersection of (R) and (S)
I is the intersection of (R) and (AE)
(OCA) = pi - (AOC) - (OAC) = pi - pi/2 + u/2 - u = pi/2-u/2 = (OAC)
So, AOC is an isosceles triangle in O.
For any (R), the arc of center O, pass through A and is tangent to At and pass through C and its tangent is parallel to (AE)
Doing the same process with the point E, we know that the jonction of the double arcs must be on (Q) of A and the (Q') of (E).
So we choose C intersection of (Q) and (Q')
